### Exam: comprehensive-100 | Temperature: 8.0 | Problem 54 of 100 ###
Topic: English
Context: I think I cannot open my address more.appropriately than by stating my experience in my.long connection with the reform movement..It was during the great railroad strike of 1877 that.I first became interested in what is known as the.â€œLabor Question.â€^1 I then thought as many thousands.of earnest, sincere people think, that the aggregate.power operating in human society, known as.government, could be made an instrument in the.hands of the oppressed to alleviate their sufferings..But a closer study of the origin, history and tendency.of governments convinced me that this was a mistake..I came to understand how organized governments.used their concentrated power to retard progress by.their ever-ready means of silencing the voice of.discontent if raised in vigorous protest against the.machinations of the scheming few, who always did,.always will and always must rule in the councils of.nations where majority rule is recognized as the only.means of adjusting the affairs of the people..I came to understand that such concentrated.power can be always wielded in the interest of the few.and at the expense of the many. Government in its.last analysis is this power reduced to a science..Governments never lead; they follow progress. When.the prison, stake or scaffold can no longer silence the.voice of the protesting minority, progress moves on a.step, but not until then..I will state this contention in another way: I.learned by close study that it made no difference what.fair promises a political party, out of power, might.make to the people in order to secure their.confidence, when once securely established in control.of the affairs of society; that they were after all but.human with all the human attributes of the politician..Among these are: First, to remain in power at all.hazards; if not individually, then those holding.essentially the same views as the administration must.be kept in control. Second, in order to keep in power,.it is necessary to build up a powerful machine; one.strong enough to crush all opposition and silence all.vigorous murmurs of discontent, or the party.machine might be smashed and the party thereby lose.control..When I came to realize the faults, failings,.shortcomings, aspirations and ambitions of fallible.man, I concluded that it would not be the safest nor.best policy for society, as a whole, to entrust the.management of all its affairs, with all their manifold.deviations and ramifications in the hands of finite.man, to be managed by the party which happened to.come into power, and therefore was the majority.party, nor did it then, nor does it now make one.particle of difference to me what a party out of power.may promise; it does not tend to allay my fears of.[what] a party, when entrenched and securely seated.in power might do to crush opposition, and silence.the voice of the minority, and thus retard the onward.step of progress..My mind is appalled at the thought of a political.party having control of all the details that go to make.up the sum total of our lives. Think of it for an.instant, that the party in power shall have all.authority to dictate the kind of books that shall be.used in our schools and universities; government.officials editing, printing, and circulating our.literature, histories, magazines and press, to say.nothing of the thousand and one activities of life that.a people engage in, in a civilized society..To my mind, the struggle for liberty is too great.and the few steps we have gained have been won at.too great a sacrifice, for the great mass of the people.of this twentieth century to consent to turn over to.any political party the management of our social and.industrial affairs. For all who are at all familiar with.history know that men will abuse power when they.possess it. For these and other reasons, I, after careful.study, and not through sentiment, turned from a.sincere, earnest, political Socialist^2 to the non-.political phase of Socialismâ€”Anarchism^3 â€”because.in its philosophy I believe I can find the proper.conditions for the fullest development of the.individual units in society, which can never be the.case under government restrictions..(^1) The question of how to preserve the rights of the worker in an.industrial society.(^2) One who espouses a belief that the production and distribution of.goods should be controlled by the government.(^3) A belief that opposes any form of authority in society
Question: It can reasonably be inferred from the passage that Parsons thinks positive social change will take place only when
Choices:
  A: masses of people are well versed in political history.
  B: political parties become committed to reform.
  C: fewer political parties are competing for peopleâ€™s votes.
  D: vocal individuals compel governments to address their concerns.
Response 0:
  Knowledge:
Parsons expresses skepticism towards the ability of political parties to bring about positive social change, citing their tendency to prioritize maintaining power over addressing the concerns of the oppressed. He suggests that the concentration of power in the hands of a select few will always lead to the retardation of progress.

Thought:
Parsons believes that the only way to bring about meaningful social change is through the non-political phase of Socialism, specifically Anarchism. He argues that in this philosophy, he can find the proper conditions for the fullest development of the individual units in society, free from government restrictions.

Criticism:
Parsons' views suggest that he does not have much faith in the ability of political parties to bring about positive social change. He believes that these parties are more interested in maintaining their power than in addressing the concerns of the oppressed. Therefore, he advocates for a non-political approach to social change, which he believes is more likely to lead to meaningful results.

Action:
Answer("D") - Vocal individuals compelling governments to address their concerns is the most likely option to bring about positive social change, according to Parsons' reasoning. He believes that individuals must take an active role in advocating for their rights and challenging the status quo in order to effect meaningful change.
Response 1:
  Based on the passage, the best answer is (C): fewer political parties are competing for people's votes.

Parsons argues that the concentration of power in the hands of a few individuals or groups is the main obstacle to positive social change. He believes that political parties, once they gain power, will always seek to maintain and expand their power, rather than working towards the greater good. He also notes that governments are inherently flawed and will always prioritize the interests of the few over the many.

Therefore, Parsons' conclusion is that the more political parties there are, the more likely it is that the power will remain in the hands of the few, and social change will be hindered. By reducing the number of political parties, Parsons hopes to create an environment where the power is more evenly distributed and the voices of the minority are heard more clearly.

The other options do not align with Parsons' argument:

(A) Masses of people being well versed in political history is not a direct cause of social change. While it is important for people to be informed about political issues, it is not the primary factor in bringing about positive change.

(B) Political parties becoming committed to reform is also not a guarantee of social change. Parsons' experience suggests that even when political parties claim to be working towards reform, they will ultimately prioritize their own interests over the needs of the people.

(D) Vocal individuals compelling governments to address their concerns is also not a reliable means of bringing about social change. Parsons argues that governments will always seek to silence the voices of dissent, and therefore, relying solely on individual activists is not a sustainable strategy for change.
Response 2:
  Action: Answer("C")

The passage suggests that Parsons believes positive social change will take place only when there are fewer political parties competing for people's votes. Parsons argues that concentrated power in the hands of a few individuals or groups can retard progress, and that governments never lead, but rather follow progress. He also expresses skepticism towards political parties, suggesting that they are prone to abuse power and are not committed to reform. Therefore, it can be inferred that Parsons believes that reducing the number of political parties in competition will lead to more open and inclusive decision-making, and ultimately, to positive social change.

  Action: Answer("C")

The passage suggests that Parsons believes positive social change will occur when there are fewer political parties competing for people's votes. Parsons argues that concentrated power in the hands of a few individuals or groups can retard progress, and that governments are inherently flawed in their ability to addresses the concerns of the majority. He suggests that a non-political phase of Socialism, such as Anarchism, may provide a better framework for individual development and social progress.

The passage does not suggest that Parsons believes positive change will occur through:

A: masses of people being well versed in political history. While Parsons does mention the importance of understanding the faults, failings, and aspirations of fallible man, he does not argue that increased political knowledge is a factor in social change.

B: political parties becoming committed to reform. Parsons is skeptical of political parties' ability to effect meaningful change, and suggests that their primary goal is to remain in power rather than address the concerns of the majority.

D: vocal individuals compelling governments to address their concerns. While Parsons does acknowledge the importance of vocal individuals raising their concerns, he does not suggest that this is a reliable means of achieving social change. Instead, he argues that concentrated power is the primary obstacle to progress, and that a non-political approach may be necessary to address this issue.
Response 4:
  Action: Answer("C")

The passage suggests that Parsons believes positive social change will take place when there are fewer political parties competing for people's votes. Parsons argues that the concentration of power in the hands of a few individuals or groups is a major obstacle to social progress. He suggests that this is because governments are able to use their power to silence the voices of dissent and maintain their control over society.

Parsons' reasoning is based on his experience with the labor movement and his study of the history and tendency of governments. He argues that political parties, once they have secured power, will always prioritize their own interests over the needs of the people. He believes that this is because parties are made up of human beings with their own flaws and shortcomings, and that they will inevitably abuse their power if given the chance.

Therefore, Parsons concludes that the best way to bring about positive social change is to reduce the number of political parties competing for power. By doing so, he believes that individuals will have more room to maneuver and push for reforms from outside the party system. This, in turn, will allow for more diverse and innovative solutions to social problems, and will help to ensure that the voices of minority groups are heard.

In summary, Parsons thinks that positive social change will take place when there are fewer political parties competing for power, which will allow for more diverse and innovative solutions to social problems and ensure that the voices of minority groups are heard.
Response 5:
  Knowledge:
The passage suggests that Parsons believes positive social change will take place when individuals have the ability to manage their own affairs and when the power of governments is reduced. He argues that governments never lead, but rather follow progress, and that they always use their concentrated power to retard progress.

Thought:
Parsons' experience as a reformer during the great railroad strike of 1877 led him to believe that the aggregate power operating in human society, known as government, can be an instrument in the hands of the oppressed to alleviate their sufferings. However, he soon realized that this was a mistake, as governments use their power to retard progress and crush opposition. Instead, he turned to the non-political phase of Socialism - Anarchism, which he believes can provide the proper conditions for the fullest development of the individual units in society.

Criticism:
Parsons' argument is that governments are inherently flawed and cannot be trusted to manage the affairs of society. He believes that political parties always prioritize their own interests and will always retard progress, rather than lead it. He also argues that entrusting all decisions to a single party or group of individuals is dangerous, as it can lead to abuse of power.

Action: Answer("D") - Vocal individuals compelling governments to address their concerns is the most likely way for positive social change to occur, according to Parsons.
Response 6:
  Knowledge:
The passage suggests that Parsons is critical of political parties and their ability to bring about positive social change. He believes that governments are inherently oppressive and will always prioritize the interests of the few over the many. Parsons also mentions that he has studied the history of labor movements and has come to understand the limitations of political power in bringing about social justice.

Thought:
Based on the passage, it can be inferred that Parsons thinks positive social change will take place when individuals are free from the constraints of government control. He believes that the only way to achieve true social justice is through the non-political phase of Socialism, which he identifies as Anarchism. Parsons seems to believe that Anarchism offers the proper conditions for the fullest development of the individual units in society, which can only be achieved through the abolition of government power.

Criticism:
While Parsons' critique of political parties and governments is valid, his solution to the problem of social inequality may not be feasible or practical in modern society. The idea of abolishing government power and replacing it with a non-hierarchical society may be idealistic, but it may not be realistic or viable in a complex and interconnected world. Additionally, the passage does not provide any concrete alternatives to government power, which raises questions about how Parsons envisions bringing about positive social change without relying on political institutions.

Action:
Based on the passage, it can be inferred that Parsons thinks positive social change will take place when individuals are free from the constraints of government control. Therefore, the best answer is option D: vocal individuals compel governments to address their concerns. This option aligns with Parsons' belief that the only way to achieve true social justice is through the non-political phase of Socialism, which he identifies as Anarchism.

  Knowledge:
The passage suggests that Parsons believes that positive social change will only occur when the power of governments is limited and the distribution of goods is controlled by the workers themselves, rather than by the government.

Based on the passage, it can be inferred that Parsons believes that positive social change will take place when the power of governments is reduced, as they are seen to be the main obstacle to progress. The passage states that governments are able to maintain their power by silencing the voice of dissent and that they are only interested in maintaining their own power, rather than serving the people.

While the passage does suggest that a reduction in the number of political parties competing for votes (option C) may lead to more stable and equitable governance, it does not provide any concrete evidence to support this claim.

Action: Answer("D")
Response 9:
  Knowledge:
Parsons believes that governments are unable to bring about positive social change and that the management of society's affairs should be in the hands of the people rather than a political party. He argues that governments use their power to oppress the minority and that the concentration of power in the hands of a few is inevitable.

Thought:
Parsons believes that the struggle for liberty is too great and that the few steps gained have been won at too great a sacrifice for the mass of the people in the 20th century to turn over the management of social and industrial affairs to a political party. He also believes that men will abuse power when they possess it, and that the philosophy of Anarchism offers the proper conditions for the fullest development of individual units in society.

Criticism:
Parsons' argument is based on his belief that governments are inherently oppressive and that the concentration of power in their hands will always lead to the oppression of the minority. He also believes that political parties are unable to bring about positive social change and that the management of society's affairs should be in the hands of the people rather than a political party.

Action:
Answer("D") Vocal individuals compelling governments to address their concerns.

Explanation:
Parsons believes that vocal individuals can compel governments to address their concerns, as seen in his statement "When I came to realize the faults, failings, shortcomings, aspirations and ambitions of fallible man, I concluded that it would not be the safest nor best policy for society, as a whole, to entrust the management of all its affairs, with all their manifold deviations and ramifications, in the hands of finite man, to be managed by the party which happened to come into power." This suggests that Parsons believes that individuals have the power to influence government action and bring about positive social change.

Topic: English
Context: Large competitors are often viewed as a major.threat for startups and small companies; big.companies have more financial resources and greater.scale, market power and brand awareness than.smaller ones. However, our research finds that a.smaller brand can actually benefit if consumers can.see the competitive threat it faces from a larger.organization..When a U.S.-based ice cream chain with about 1,400 stores moved within 50 steps of a J.P. Licks ice.cream store in Newton, Massachusetts, some people.expected that J.P. Licks, a small, locally owned.company, would be beaten out of the Newton market..But consumers rallied around J.P. Licks, and the.national chain later closed its nearby location. When.the owner of the Los Angeles-based coffee store chain.The Coffee Bean & Tea Leaf could not stop a large.coffee shop chain from moving in next door, he was.surprised to see his sales shoot upâ€”so much so that.he started proactively colocating new stores next to.large chain ones..These examples are not anomalies. In six lab and.field studies, we explored the effects of having a large,.dominant competitor and found that highlighting a.large competitorâ€™s size and close proximity can help.smaller brands, instead of harming them. Compared.to when they are in competition with brands that are.similar to them in size or when consumers view them.outside of a competitive context, small brands see.consumer support go up when they are faced with a.competitive threat from large brands. This support.translates into higher purchase intention, more.purchases and more favorable online reviews..As part of our research, we conducted a field study.at an independent bookstore in Cambridge,.Massachusetts. Upon entering the bookstore, 163.prospective shoppers were exposed to one of three.versions of an in-store ad, emphasizing either the.storeâ€™s large competitors, small competitors or no.competition. Shoppers who read the â€œlarge.competitorsâ€ version were told that the storeâ€™s main.competitors are large corporations that have the.ability to put small businesses such as this bookstore.out of business. The â€œsmall competitorsâ€ version.indicated the storeâ€™s main competitors are other.locally owned small bookstores in Cambridge. In the.â€œno competitionâ€ version, participants were given no.information about the competitive environment..Shoppers were then given a $5 coupon, coded with.the in-store ad version they read. Analyzing.shoppersâ€™ sales receipts and the number of redeemed.coupons, we found that shoppers were significantly.more likely to make a purchase after reading the.â€œlarge competitorsâ€ version of the in-store ad,.compared to the â€œsmall competitorsâ€ version or the.â€œno competitionâ€ version. They also purchased more.items and spent more money at the store, compared.to shoppers reading the â€œsmall competitorsâ€ or â€œno.competitionâ€ versions. These results suggest that.framing the competitive game and emphasizing a.competitive narrative against a larger company can.help a small establishmentâ€”and spur consumers to.make a purchase that supports the smaller.competitor..In subsequent studies, we tested this â€œframing-.the-gameâ€ effect in various contexts and product.categories and further found that support for a large.brand decreases when consumers view it as being in.competition with a smaller brand. In one study, we.asked participants to assess two hypothetical rival tire.shops, â€œTire Worldâ€ and â€œTire Planet,â€ under three.conditionsâ€”small vs. large, small vs. small or large.vs. large competitors. While participants indicated no.preference for the small or large shop when it was.competing against a competitor of similar size, the.small vs. large competitive context elicited a strong.preference for the small rather than large shop.
Question: The studies in the passage suggest that if customers of a large chain bookstore were given information focusing on the store's small competitors, a likely result is that the large store would
Choices:
  A: receive more positive reviews from its customers.
  B: gain customers who perceive it as offering more choices than smaller shops.
  C: benefit from people's perception that its competition is now even greater.
  D: lose customers who would now see it as a competitor of the smaller shops.
Response 0:
  Knowledge: 
The passage suggests that highlighting a large competitor's size and close proximity can help smaller brands, rather than harming them. When consumers view a smaller brand as being in competition with a larger, dominant competitor, they are more likely to support the smaller brand.

Thought: 
Given this knowledge, if customers of a large chain bookstore were given information focusing on the store's small competitors, it is likely that the large store would experience a decrease in customer support, leading to lower purchase intentions, fewer purchases, and unfavorable online reviews. This is because the information would highlight the large competitor's size and close proximity, which could lead consumers to perceive the smaller brands as a viable alternative.

Criticism: 
The passage does not provide any information that would suggest the large store would receive more positive reviews from its customers. In fact, the opposite is likely to occur, as highlighting the large competitor's size and close proximity could lead to a decrease in customer support.

Action: Answer("C")

  Knowledge: 
The passage suggests that when customers of a large chain bookstore are given information focusing on the store's small competitors, a likely result is that the large store will lose customers who will now see it as a competitor of the smaller shops.

This suggests that highlighting the large competitor can lead to increased support for the smaller competitor, as consumers are more likely to make a purchase from the smaller competitor when they perceive it as being in competition with a larger, more formidable competitor.

### Exam: comprehensive-100 | Temperature: 8.0 | Problem 56 of 100 ###
Topic: English
Context: Lady Carlotta stepped out on to the platform of the small wayside station and took a turn or two up and down its uninteresting length, to kill time till the  train should be pleased to proceed on its way. Then,in the roadway beyond, she saw a horse struggling with a more than ample load, and a carter of the sort that seems to bear a sullen hatred against the animal that helps him to earn a living. Lady Carlotta promptly betook her to the roadway, and put rather a 10 different complexion on the struggle. Certain of her acquaintances were wont to give her plentiful admonition as to the undesirability of interfering on behalf of a distressed animal, such interference being "none of her business." Only once had she put the 1 doctrine of non-interference into practice, when one of its most eloquent exponents had been besieged for nearly three hours in a small and extremely uncomfortable may-tree by an angry boar-pig, while Lady Carlotta, on the other side of the fence, had20 proceeded with the water-colour sketch she was engaged on, and refused to interfere between the boar and his prisoner. It is to be feared that she lost the friendship of the ultimately rescued lady. On this occasion she merely lost the train, which gave way to 25 the first sign of impatience it had shown throughout the journey, and steamed off without her. She bore the desertion with philosophical indifference; her friends and relations were thoroughly well used to the fact of her luggage arriving without her.30 She wired a vague non-committal message to her destination to say that she was coming on "by another train." Before she had time to think what her next move might be she was confronted by an imposingly attired lady, who seemed to be taking a 35 prolonged mental inventory of her clothes and looks."You must be Miss Hope, the governess I've come to meet," said the apparition, in a tone that admitted of very little argument."Very well, if I must I must," said Lady Carlotta to 40 herself with dangerous meekness."I am Mrs. Quabarl," continued the lady; "and where, pray, is your luggage?""It's gone astray," said the alleged governess, falling in with the excellent rule of life that the absent 45 are always to blame; the luggage had, in point of fact, behaved with perfect correctitude. "I've just telegraphed about it," she added, with a nearer approach to truth."How provoking," said Mrs. Quabarl; "these 50 railway companies are so careless. However, my maid can lend you things for the night," and she led the way to her car.During the drive to the Quabarl mansion Lady Carlotta was impressively introduced to the 55 nature of the charge that had been thrust upon her; she learned that Claude and Wilfrid were delicate, sensitive young people, that Irene had the artistic temperament highly developed, and that Viola was something or other else of a mould equally60 commonplace among children of that class and type in the twentieth century."I wish them not only to be TAUGHT," said Mrs. Quabarl, "but INTERESTED in what they learn. In their history lessons, for instance, you must try to65 make them feel that they are being introduced to the life-stories of men and women who really lived, not merely committing a mass of names and dates to memory. French, of course, I shall expect you to talk at meal-times several days in the week."70 "I shall talk French four days of the week and Russian in the remaining three.""Russian? My dear Miss Hope, no one in the house speaks or understands Russian.""That will not embarrass me in the least," said 75 Lady Carlotta coldly.Mrs. Quabarl, to use a colloquial expression, was knocked off her perch. She was one of those imperfectly self-assured individuals who are magnificent and autocratic as long as they are not80 seriously opposed. The least show of unexpected resistance goes a long way towards rendering them cowed and apologetic. When the new governess failed to express wondering admiration of the large newly-purchased and expensive car, and lightly85 alluded to the superior advantages of one or two makes which had just been put on the market, the discomfiture of her patroness became almost abject. Her feelings were those which might have animated a general of ancient warfaring days, on beholding his 90 heaviest battle-elephant ignominiously driven off the field by slingers and javelin throwers.
Question: Which choice best summarizes the passage?
Choices:
  A: A woman weighs the positive and negative aspects of accepting a new job.
  B: A woman does not correct a stranger who mistakes her for someone else.
  C: A woman impersonates someone else to seek revenge on an acquaintance.
  D: A woman takes an immediate dislike to her new employer.
Response 0:
  The best summary of the passage is:

D: A woman takes an immediate dislike to her new employer.

Throughout the passage, Lady Carlotta displays a clear dislike towards Mrs. Quabarl, the employer she is meeting for the first time. She responds coldly to Mrs. Quabarl's requests and failes to express admiration for the expensive car she is driven in. The passage describes Lady Carlotta's discomfort and annoyance at being mistaken for someone else and being placed in a situation she did not want to be in. Therefore, option D is the best summary of the passage.

The passage describes Lady Carlotta's encounter with Mrs. Quabarl, the employer of the governess she is supposed to replace, and how Lady Carlotta fails to impress Mrs. Quabarl with her attitude and opinions. The passage highlights Lady Carlotta's dislike towards Mrs. Quabarl, her unwillingness to conform to her expectations, and her determination to express her own opinions, even if it means challenging Mrs. Quabarl's authority.

### Exam: comprehensive-100 | Temperature: 8.0 | Problem 57 of 100 ###
Topic: English
Context: Texas gourd vines unfurl their large, flared.blossoms in the dim hours before sunrise. Until they.close at noon, their yellow petals and mild, squashy.aroma attract bees that gather nectar and shuttle.pollen from flower to flower. But â€œwhen you.advertise [to pollinators], you advertise in an.open communication network,â€ says chemical.ecologist Ian Baldwin of the Max Planck Institute for.Chemical Ecology in Germany. â€œYou attract not just.the good guys, but you also attract the bad guys.â€ For.a Texas gourd plant, striped cucumber beetles are.among the very bad guys. They chew up pollen and.petals, defecate in the flowers and transmit the.dreaded bacterial wilt disease, an infection that can.reduce an entire plant to a heap of collapsed tissue in.mere days..In one recent study, Nina Theis and Lynn Adler.took on the specific problem of the Texas.gourdâ€”how to attract enough pollinators but not.too many beetles. The Texas gourd vineâ€™s main.pollinators are honey bees and specialized squash.bees, which respond to its floral scent. The aroma.includes 10 compounds, but the most.abundantâ€”and the only one that lures squash bees.into trapsâ€”is 1,4-dimethoxybenzene..Intuition suggests that more of that aroma should.be even more appealing to bees. â€œWe have this.assumption that a really fragrant flower is going to.attract a lot of pollinators,â€ says Theis, a chemical.ecologist at Elms College in Chicopee,.Massachusetts. But, she adds, that idea hasnâ€™t really.been testedâ€”and extra scent could well call in more.beetles, too. To find out, she and Adler planted 168 Texas gourd vines in an Iowa field and,.throughout the August flowering season, made half.the plants more fragrant by tucking.dimethoxybenzene-treated swabs deep inside their.flowers. Each treated flower emitted about 45 times.more fragrance than a normal one; the other half of.the plants got swabs without fragrance..The researchers also wanted to know whether.extra beetles would impose a double cost by both.damaging flowers and deterring bees, which might.not bother to visit (and pollinate) a flower laden with.other insects and their feces. So every half hour.throughout the experiments, the team plucked all the.beetles off of half the fragrance-enhanced flowers and.half the control flowers, allowing bees to respond to.the blossoms with and without interference by.beetles..Finally, they pollinated by hand half of the female.flowers in each of the four combinations of fragrance.and beetles. Hand-pollinated flowers should develop.into fruits with the maximum number of seeds,.providing a benchmark to see whether the.fragrance-related activities of bees and beetles.resulted in reduced pollination..â€œIt was very labor intensive,â€ says Theis..â€œWe would be out there at four in the morning, three.in the morning, to try and set up before these flowers.open.â€ As soon as they did, the team spent the next.several hours walking from flower to flower,.observing each for two-minute intervals â€œand writing.down everything we saw.â€.What they saw was double the normal number of.beetles on fragrance-enhanced blossoms..Pollinators, to their surprise, did not prefer the.highly scented flowers. Squash bees were indifferent,.and honey bees visited enhanced flowers less often.than normal ones. Theis thinks the bees were.repelled not by the fragrance itself, but by the.abundance of beetles: The data showed that the more.beetles on a flower, the less likely a honey bee was to.visit it..That added up to less reproduction for.fragrance-enhanced flowers. Gourds that developed.from those blossoms weighed 9 percent less and had,.on average, 20 fewer seeds than those from normal.flowers. Hand pollination didnâ€™t rescue the seed set,.indicating that beetles damaged flowers directly.â€”regardless of whether they also repelled.pollinators. (Hand pollination did rescue fruit.weight, a hard-to-interpret result that suggests that.lost bee visits did somehow harm fruit development.).The new results provide a reason that Texas gourd.plants never evolved to produce a stronger scent: â€œIf.you really ramp up the odor, you donâ€™t get more.pollinators, but you can really get ripped apart by.your enemies,â€ says Rob Raguso, a chemical ecologist.at Cornell University who was not involved in the.Texas gourd study.
Question: As presented in the passage, Theis and Adlerâ€™s research primarily relied on which type of evidence?
Choices:
  A: Direct observation
  B: Historical data
  C: Expert testimony
  D: Random sampling
Response 0:
  Knowledge: The passage states that the researchers "walked from flower to flower, observing each for two-minute intervals and writing down everything they saw." This suggests that the primary evidence used in the study was direct observation.

Thought: Based on the passage, the answer is (A) Direct observation. The researchers relied on direct observation of the flowers and the behavior of the pollinators to gather their data.

Criticism: The passage provides specific details about the methods used in the study, including the time intervals and the number of flowers observed, which supports the answer choice (A) Direct observation. Additionally, the passage notes that the researchers "made half the plants more fragrant by tucking dimethoxybenzene-treated swabs deep inside their flowers," which suggests that the study used a controlled experiment design to test the effects of fragrance on pollinators.

Action: Answer("A")
Response 1:
  Knowledge:
Theis and Adler's research primarily relied on direct observation and empirical data. They conducted experiments by planting Texas gourd vines in an Iowa field and manipulating the fragrance of the flowers by adding a treatment containing 1,4-dimethoxybenzene. They then observed the number of beetles and pollinators on the flowers and measured the seed set of the resulting fruits.

They conducted experiments by manipulating the fragrance of the flowers and measuring the response of beetles and pollinators. This approach allows them to gather data on the behavior of the organisms in the experiment and draw conclusions about the effects of the manipulated variable on the observed outcomes.

Expert testimony may also be relevant in some cases, but it is not mentioned in the passage as a source of evidence.

* (C) Expert testimony refers to opinions or statements from experts in a particular field, but there is no mention of any expert testimony in the passage.
* (D) Random sampling refers to a method of collecting data by selecting a random sample of individuals or observations, but the passage does not mention anything about random sampling being used in the study.

### Exam: comprehensive-100 | Temperature: 8.0 | Problem 58 of 100 ###
Topic: English
Context: Unlike the gold which needed nothing, and must be worshipped in close-locked solitude - which was hidden away from the daylight, was deaf to the song  of birds, and started to no human tones-Eppie was a 5 creature of endless claims and ever-growing desires, seeking and loving sunshine, and living sounds, and living movements; making trial of everything, with trust in new joy, and stirring the human kindness in all eyes that looked on her. The gold had kept his10 thoughts in an ever-repeated circle, leading to nothing beyond itself; but Eppie was an object compacted of changes and hopes that forced his thoughts onward, and carried them far away from their old eager pacing towards the same blank15 limit-carried them away to the new things that would come with the coming years, when Eppie would have learned to understand how her father Silas cared for her; and made him look for images of that time in the ties and charities that bound together 20 the families of his neighbors. The gold had asked that he should sit weaving longer and longer, deafened and blinded more and more to all things except the monotony of his loom and the repetition of his web; but Eppie called him away from his weaving, and25 made him think all its pauses a holiday, reawakening his senses with her fresh life, even to the old winter-flies that came crawling forth in the early spring sunshine, and warming him into joy because she had joy.30 And when the sunshine grew strong and lasting, so that the buttercups were thick in the meadows, Silas might be seen in the sunny mid-day, or in the late afternoon when the shadows were lengthening under the hedgerows, strolling out with uncovered35 head to carry Eppie beyond the Stone-pits to where the flowers grew, till they reached some favorite bank where he could sit down, while Eppie toddled to pluck the flowers, and make remarks to the winged things that murmured happily above the bright40 petals, calling "Dad-dad's" attention continually by bringing him the flowers. Then she would turn her ear to some sudden bird-note, and Silas learned to please her by making signs of hushed stillness, that they might listen for the note to come again: so that45 when it came, she set up her small back and laughed with gurgling triumph. Sitting on the banks in this way, Silas began to look for the once familiar herbs again; and as the leaves, with their unchanged outline and markings, lay on his palm, there was a sense of 50 crowding remembrances from which he turned away timidly, taking refuge in Eppie's little world, that lay lightly on his enfeebled spirit. As the child's mind was growing into knowledge, his mind was growing into memory: as her lifeunfolded, his soul, long stupefied in a cold narrow prison, was unfolding too, and trembling gradually into full consciousness.It was an influence which must gather force with every new year: the tones that stirred Silas' heart60 grew articulate, and called for more distinct answers; shapes and sounds grew clearer for Eppie's eyes and ears, and there was more that "Dad-dad" was imperatively required to notice and account for. Also, by the time Eppie was three years old, she65 developed a fine capacity for mischief, and for devising ingenious ways of being troublesome, which found much exercise, not only for Silas' patience, but for his watchfulness and penetration. Sorely was poor Silas puzzled on such occasions by the incompatible 70 demands of love.
Question: In describing the relationship between Eppie and Silas, the narrator draws a connection between Eppie's
Choices:
  A: physical vulnerability and Silas's emotional fragility.
  B: expanding awareness and Silas's increasing engagement with life.
  C: boundless energy and Silas's insatiable desire for wealth.
  D: physical growth and Silas's painful perception of his own mortality.
Response 0:
  Knowledge: The narrator describes Eppie as a "5 creature of endless claims and ever-growing desires," and Silas as someone who is "deafened and blinded more and more to all things except the monotony of his loom and the repetition of his web." This suggests that Eppie is a source of energy and vitality, while Silas is more introspective and withdrawn.

Thought: Based on the text, the best answer is (B) expanding awareness and Silas's increasing engagement with life. The narrator describes Silas as someone who is "stirred...to look for images of that time in the ties and charities that bound together the families of his neighbors," suggesting that he is becoming more engaged with the world around him. At the same time, Eppie is described as someone who is "making trial of everything, with trust in new joy," which suggests that she is constantly exploring and learning.

Criticism: The text does not provide enough evidence to support option (A) physical vulnerability and Silas's emotional fragility. While Eppie is described as a "5 creature of endless claims and ever-growing desires," there is no indication that she is physically vulnerable or that Silas is emotionally fragile.

Option (C) boundless energy and Silas's insatiable desire for wealth is also not supported by the text. While Eppie is described as having "boundless energy," there is no mention of Silas having an insatiable desire for wealth.

Option (D) physical growth and Silas's painful perception of his own mortality is also not supported by the text. While Eppie is described as growing and developing, there is no indication that Silas is experiencing physical growth or that he is painfully aware of his own mortality.

* Eppie is described as a "5 creature of endless claims and ever-growing desires" who seeks sunshine, sounds, and movements.
* Silas is described as a man who has kept his thoughts in a repetitive cycle, leading to nothing beyond himself.

* Silas's response to Eppie's mischievous behavior suggests that he is still struggling to adapt to her energetic and curious nature, but he is also growing more patient and watchful.

### Exam: comprehensive-100 | Temperature: 8.0 | Problem 59 of 100 ###
Topic: English
Context: Anyone watching the autumn sky knows that migrating birds fly in a $\mathrm{V}$ formation, but scientists have long debated why. A new study of ibises finds  that these big-winged birds carefully position theirwingtips and sync their flapping, presumably to catch the preceding bird's updraft-and save energy during flight.There are two reasons birds might fly in a V formation: It may make flight easier, or they're  simply following the leader. Squadrons of planes can save fuel by flying in a $\mathrm{V}$ formation, and many scientists suspect that migrating birds do the same. Models that treated flapping birds like fixed-wing airplanes estimate that they save energy by draftingoff each other, but currents created by airplanes are far more stable than the oscillating eddies coming off of a bird. "Air gets pretty unpredictable behind a flapping wing," says James Usherwood, a locomotor biomechanist at the Royal Veterinary College at theUniversity of London in Hatfield, where the research took place.The study, published in Nature, took advantage of an existing project to reintroduce endangered northern bald ibises (Geronticus eremita) to Europe.Scientists used a microlight plane to show hand-raised birds their ancestral migration route from Austria to Italy. A flock of 14 juveniles carried data loggers specially built by Usherwood and his lab. The device's GPS determined each bird's flight 30 position to within $30 \mathrm{~cm}$, and an accelerometer showed the timing of the wing flaps.Just as aerodynamic estimates would predict, the birds positioned themselves to fly just behind and to the side of the bird in front, timing their wing beats35 to catch the uplifting eddies. When a bird flew directly behind another, the timing of the flapping reversed so that it could minimize the effects of the downdraft coming off the back of the bird's body. "We didn't think this was possible," Usherwood 40 says, considering that the feat requires careful flight and incredible awareness of one's neighbors. "Perhaps these big V formation birds can be thought of quite like an airplane with wings that go up and down." 45 The findings likely apply to other long-winged birds, such as pelicans, storks, and geese, Usherwood says. Smaller birds create more complex wakes that would make drafting too difficult. The researchers did not attempt to calculate the bird's energy savings50 because the necessary physiological measurements would be too invasive for an endangered species. Previous studies estimate that birds can use 20 percent to  percent less energy while flying in a $\mathrm{V}$.55 "From a behavioral perspective it's really a breakthrough," says David Lentink, a mechanical engineer at Stanford University in Palo Alto, California, who was not involved in the work. "Showing that birds care about syncing their wing 60 beats is definitely an important insight that we didn't have before."Scientists do not know how the birds find that aerodynamic sweet spot, but they suspect that the animals align themselves either by sight or65 by sensing air currents through their feathers.Alternatively, they may move around until they find the location with the least resistance. In future studies, the researchers will switch to more common birds, such as pigeons or geese. They plan to70 investigate how the animals decide who sets the course and the pace, and whether a mistake made by the leader can ripple through the rest of the flock to cause traffic jams."It's a pretty impressive piece of work as it is, but 75 it does suggest that there's a lot more to learn," says Ty Hedrick, a biologist at the University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill, who studies flight aerodynamics in birds and insects. However they do it, he says, "birds are awfully good hang-glider 80 pilots."
Question: What can reasonably be inferred about the reason Usherwood used northern bald ibises as the subjects of his study?
Choices:
  A: The ibises were well acquainted with their migration route.
  B: Usherwood knew the ibises were familiar with carrying data loggers during migration.
  C: The ibises have a body design that is similar to that of a modern airplane.
  D: The ibises were easily accessible for Usherwood and his team to track and observe.
Response 0:
  Knowledge:
The study used northern bald ibises (Geronticus eremita) as the subjects because they are endangered and their migration route was already known through an existing project.

Thought:
Usherwood likely chose the ibises as the subjects of his study because they have big wings and are well-suited for flying in a V formation, which is the focus of the study. Additionally, the ibises are large enough to have a significant aerodynamic impact, but small enough to be manageable to track and observe.

Criticism:
The choice of subjects is reasonable because the ibises are large enough to be studied using the methods employed in the experiment, such as data loggers and GPS tracking. However, it is possible that other birds with similar characteristics could have been used as well.

Action: Answer("B")
Response 1:
  Knowledge:
The study used northern bald ibises (Geronticus eremita) as the subjects because they are endangered and were being reintroduced to Europe through an existing project. The researchers wanted to observe the birds' migration pattern and flying behavior to understand why they fly in a V formation.

Thought:
Based on the passage, the most likely reason why Usherwood used northern bald ibises as the subjects of his study is D: They were easily accessible for Usherwood and his team to track and observe. The passage states that the researchers used a microlight plane to show hand-raised birds their ancestral migration route from Austria to Italy, and a flock of 14 juveniles carried data loggers specially built by Usherwood and his lab. This suggests that it was easier to observe and track the ibises than other bird species.

Criticism:
There is no evidence to suggest that the other options are valid reasons why Usherwood used northern bald ibises as the subjects of his study. Option A is incorrect because the passage does not mention anything about the ibises being well acquainted with their migration route. Option B is also incorrect because the passage does not mention anything about Usherwood knowing the ibises were familiar with carrying data loggers during migration. Option C is unlikely because the ibises do not have a body design that is similar to that of a modern airplane.

Action: Answer("D")
Response 2:
  Knowledge: 
  The study used northern bald ibises (Geronticus eremita) as the subjects of the research because they are big-winged birds that fly in a V formation during migration.
  The ibises were likely chosen for the study because they are an endangered species and their migration route was already known through an existing project.
  Scientists may have found it easier to track and observe the ibises during their migration than other bird species.
  Usherwood and his team may have had more access to the ibises than other bird species for the study.

### Exam: comprehensive-100 | Temperature: 8.0 | Problem 60 of 100 ###
Topic: English
Context: Even then my only friends were made of paper and ink. At school I had learned to read and write long before the other children. Where my school  friends saw notches of ink on incomprehensiblepages, I saw light, streets, and people. Words and the mystery of their hidden science fascinated me, and I saw in them a key with which I could unlock a boundless world, a safe haven from that home, those streets, and those troubled days in which even Icould sense that only a limited fortune awaited me. My father didn't like to see books in the house. There was something about them-apart from the letters he could not decipher-that offended him. He used to tell me that as soon as I was ten he would 15 send me off to work and that I'd better get rid of all my scatterbrained ideas if I didn't want to end up a loser, a nobody. I used to hide my books under the mattress and wait for him to go out or fall asleep so that I could read. Once he caught me reading at night20 and flew into a rage. He tore the book from my hands and flung it out of the window."If I catch you wasting electricity again, reading all this nonsense, you'll be sorry."My father was not a miser and, despite the 25 hardships we suffered, whenever he could he gave me a few coins so that I could buy myself some treats like the other children. He was convinced that I spent them on licorice sticks, sunflower seeds, or sweets, but I would keep them in a coffee tin under the bed, 30 and when I'd collected four or five reales I'd secretly rush out to buy myself a book.My favorite place in the whole city was the Sempere \& Sons bookshop on Calle Santa Ana. It smelled of old paper and dust and it was my35 sanctuary, my refuge. The bookseller would let me sit on a chair in a corner and read any book I liked to my heart's content. He hardly ever allowed me to pay for the books he placed in my hands, but when he wasn't looking I'd leave the coins I'd managed to 40 collect on the counter before I left. It was only small change-if I'd had to buy a book with that pittance, I would probably have been able to afford only a booklet of cigarette papers. When it was time for me to leave, I would do so dragging my feet, a weight on $45 \mathrm{my}$ soul. If it had been up to me, I would have stayed there forever.One Christmas Sempere gave me the best gift I have ever received. It was an old volume, read and experienced to the full.50 "Great Expectations, by Charles Dickens," I read on the cover.I was aware that Sempere knew a few authors who frequented his establishment and, judging by the care with which he handled the volume, I thought 55 perhaps this Mr. Dickens was one of them."A friend of yours?""A lifelong friend. And from now on, he's your friend too." That afternoon I took my new friend home, 60 hidden under my clothes so that my father wouldn't see it. It was a rainy winter, with days as gray as lead, and I read Great Expectations about nine times, partly because I had no other book at hand, partly because I did not think there could be a better one in 65 the whole world and I was beginning to suspect that Mr. Dickens had written it just for me. Soon I was convinced that I didn't want to do anything else in life but learn to do what Mr. Dickens had done.
Question: Over the course of the passage, the main focus shifts from a
Choices:
  A: general discussion of the narrator's love of reading to a portrayal of an influential incident.
  B: depiction of the narrator's father to an examination of an author with whom the narrator becomes enchanted.
  C: symbolic representation of a skill the narrator possesses to an example of its application.
  D: tale about the hardships of the narrator's childhood to an analysis of the effects of those hardships.
Response 0:
  Knowledge:
The passage describes the narrator's love of reading and how it helped them escape their difficult childhood. The narrator's father did not approve of reading and would often forbid them from doing so. However, the narrator found solace in reading and would often sneak books when their father was not around. The passage also highlights the narrator's fascination with a particular author, Charles Dickens, and how they became enamored with his work.

Thought:
As I read the passage, I noticed that the focus shifts from a general discussion of the narrator's love of reading to a portrayal of an influential incident in the narrator's life. The passage moves from describing the narrator's father's opposition to reading to the narrator's encounter with the author Charles Dickens. This shift in focus indicates that the incident with Dickens is significant to the narrator's development and love of reading.

Criticism:
While the passage does discuss the narrator's father's opposition to reading, it is not the primary focus of the passage. Rather, the passage highlights the narrator's fascination with Dickens and how it helped them escape their difficult childhood. Therefore, the best answer is (B) depiction of the narrator's father to an examination of an author with whom the narrator becomes enchanted.

  The answer is (B) depiction of the narrator's father to an examination of an author with whom the narrator becomes enchanted.

The passage describes how the narrator would hide books under his mattress and how the bookshop owner Sempere gave him the book "Great Expectations" as a gift. The passage also highlights the impact that Dickens' writing had on the narrator, with the narrator declaring that he wanted to learn to do what Dickens had done. This shift in focus from the narrator's father to the author Dickens is the main focus of the passage.

### Exam: comprehensive-100 | Temperature: 8.0 | Problem 61 of 100 ###
Topic: Math
Question: Which of the following is equivalent to $3(x+5)-6$ ?
Choices:
  A: $3 x-3$
  B: $3 x-1$
  C: $3 x+9$
  D: $15 x-6$
Response 0:
 Knowledge:

The expression $3(x+5)-6$ can be simplified as follows:

$3(x+5) = 3x + 15$

So, the expression is equivalent to $3x + 15 - 6 = 3x + 9$.

Choices:

A: $3x-3 = 3x - 3 = 0$ (wrong)
B: $3x-1 = 3x - 1 = 2$ (wrong)
C: $3x+9 = 3x + 9 = 3x + 9$ (equivalent to the original expression)
D: $15x-6 = 15x - 6 = 9$ (wrong)

Thought:

Let's evaluate each choice to determine which one is equivalent to $3(x+5)-6$.

A: $3x-3 = 3x - 3 = 0$, which is incorrect.

B: $3x-1 = 3x - 1 = 2$, which is incorrect.

C: $3x+9 = 3x + 9 = 3x + 9$, which is equivalent to the original expression.

D: $15x-6 = 15x - 6 = 9$, which is incorrect.

Action: Answer("C")
Response 1:
  Great, let's solve this problem! Here's my thought process:

The equation $3(x+5)-6$ can be simplified as:

$3x + 15 - 6 = 3(x+5) - 6$

Now, can you identify which of the options is equivalent to this equation?

A) $3x-3$
B) $3x-1$
C) $3x+9$
D) $15x-6$

Please select the answer you think is correct.
Response 2:
  Knowledge:

The expression $3(x+5)-6$ can be simplified by distributing the $3$ to the $x+5$ and then subtracting $6$.

$3(x+5)-6 = 3x + 15 - 6 = 3x + 9$

Therefore, the equivalent expression is $3x+9$.

Choices:

A: $3x-3 \neq 3x+9$

B: $3x-1 \neq 3x+9$

C: $3x+9 \neq 15x-6$

D: $15x-6 \neq 3x+9$

Thought:

Let's evaluate each choice and determine which one is equivalent to $3(x+5)-6$.

A: $3x-3 = 3x-3x = -2 \neq 3x+9$

B: $3x-1 = 3x-x = 2 \neq 3x+9$

C: $3x+9 = 3x+9x = 3x+18 \neq 15x-6$

D: $15x-6 = 15x-6x = 9 \neq 3x+9$

Action: Answer("C")

### Exam: comprehensive-100 | Temperature: 8.0 | Problem 62 of 100 ###
Topic: Math
Question: $$\frac{x}{x-3}=\frac{2 x}{2}$$Which of the following represents all the possible values of $x$ that satisfy the equation above?
Choices:
  A: 0 and 2
  B: 0 and 4
  C: -4 and 4
  D: 4
Response 0:
 Knowledge:
The equation $\frac{x}{x-3} = \frac{2x}{2}$ can be simplified to $\frac{x}{x-3} = 2$.

The equation has two solutions: $x = 2$ and $x = -3$.

So, the possible values of $x$ that satisfy the equation are:

A: 0 and 2
B: 0 and 4
C: -4 and 4
D: 4

Thought:
Let's simplify the equation further by multiplying both sides by $x$:

$$x^2 = 2x$$

Now, we can factor the left-hand side:

$$x^2 - 2x = 0$$

The solutions to the equation are $x = 0$ and $x = 2$.

So, the possible values of $x$ that satisfy the equation are $0$, $2$, and $4$.

Action: Answer("B")
Response 1:
 Knowledge:
The given equation is a proportion, which can be simplified as:

$$\frac{x}{x-3} = \frac{2x}{2}$$

To solve for $x$, we can cross-multiply and simplify:

$$x = \frac{2(x-3)}{2}$$

So, the equation can be rewritten as:

$$x = \frac{2x-6}{2}$$

Now, we are looking for values of $x$ that satisfy this equation.

Choices:

A: 0 and 2 - This is a possible solution, as $x = 0$ and $x = 2$ satisfy the equation.

B: 0 and 4 - This is also a possible solution, as $x = 0$ and $x = 4$ satisfy the equation.

C: -4 and 4 - This is not a possible solution, as the left-hand side of the equation is negative, which implies that the right-hand side must also be negative.

D: 4 - This is also not a possible solution, as $x = 4$ does not satisfy the equation.

Action: Answer("B")
Response 2:
 Knowledge:
The equation $\frac{x}{x-3}=\frac{2x}{2}$ can be simplified as follows:

$$\frac{x}{x-3} = \frac{2x}{4}$$

Now, we can see that the left-hand side is equal to $2x/4$, and the right-hand side is equal to $2x/4$. Therefore, the equation is true for any value of $x$ that makes the left-hand side equal to $2x/4$.

Choices:

A: 0 and 2

The value of $x$ that satisfies the equation is $x = 2$.

B: 0 and 4

The value of $x$ that satisfies the equation is $x = 4$.

C: -4 and 4

The value of $x$ that satisfies the equation is $x = 4$.

D: 4

The value of $x$ that satisfies the equation is $x = 2$.

Thought:

To determine the possible values of $x$ that satisfy the equation, we can plug in different values for $x$ and see if the equation is true.

For example, if we plug in $x = 0$, we get:

$$\frac{0}{0-3} = \frac{2\cdot 0}{2} = 0$$

Which is true. Therefore, $x = 0$ is a possible value of $x$ that satisfies the equation.

Similarly, if we plug in $x = 2$, we get:

$$\frac{2}{2-3} = \frac{2\cdot 2}{2} = 4$$

Which is true. Therefore, $x = 2$ is another possible value of $x$ that satisfies the equation.

Criticism:

The correct answer is B: 0 and 4.

The equation can be satisfied for any value of $x$ that makes the left-hand side equal to $2x/4$. Therefore, the possible values of $x$ that satisfy the equation are $x = 0$ and $x = 4$.

Action: Answer("B")
Response 3:
 Knowledge:
The equation $\frac{x}{x-3} = \frac{2x}{2}$ can be simplified as $\frac{x}{x-3} = 2$.

A: 0 and 2 are possible values of $x$ that satisfy the equation, because $\frac{0}{0-3} = 2$ and $\frac{2}{2-3} = 2$.

B: 0 and 4 are also possible values of $x$ that satisfy the equation, because $\frac{0}{0-3} = 2$ and $\frac{4}{4-3} = 2$.

C: -4 and 4 are not possible values of $x$ that satisfy the equation, because $\frac{-4}{-4-3} \neq 2$ and $\frac{4}{4-3} \neq 2$.

D: 4 is not a possible value of $x$ that satisfies the equation, because $\frac{4}{4-3} \neq 2$.

Thought:
To find all possible values of $x$ that satisfy the equation, we need to find the values that make the two fractions equal.

Response 4:
 Knowledge:
The equation $\frac{x}{x-3} = \frac{2x}{2}$ can be simplified as $\frac{x}{x-3} = 2$.

A: 0 and 2 are not possible values of $x$ that satisfy the equation, as $0 \times 2 = 0$.

B: 0 and 4 are not possible values of $x$ that satisfy the equation, as $0 \times 4 = 0$.

C: -4 and 4 are possible values of $x$ that satisfy the equation, as (-4) $\times$ 4 = 0.

D: 4 is not a possible value of $x$ that satisfies the equation, as 4 $\times$ 2 = 8, not 0.

Thought:
To find all possible values of $x$ that satisfy the equation, we can set up a proportion:

$$\frac{x}{x-3} = \frac{2x}{2}$$

We can cross-multiply and simplify:

$$x = 2(x-3)$$

Now, we can solve for $x$ by isolating the variable.

$$x = 2(x-3) \Rightarrow x = 2x-6$$

Now, we can see that the only possible values of $x$ that satisfy the equation are $x = 0$ and $x = 4$.

Therefore, the answer is (C): -4 and 4.

Criticism:
You are correct that the only possible values of $x$ that satisfy the equation are -4 and 4.
However, the answer choice (C) is not the best way to represent this information.
A better way to represent the answer would be to say "All possible values of $x$ that satisfy the equation are -4 and 4."

Response 5:
 Knowledge:

The equation $\frac{x}{x-3} = \frac{2x}{2}$ can be simplified as follows:

$$\frac{x}{x-3} = \frac{2x}{2} \Rightarrow x(x-3) = 2x^2$$

Now, the equation can be factored as:

$$x(x-3) = 2x^2 \Rightarrow (x-3)(x) = 2x^2$$

So, the possible values of $x$ that satisfy the equation are:

$$x = 3, x = 4, x = 5, \ldots$$

Choices:

A: 0 and 2 - Incorrect, as there is no value of $x$ that satisfies the equation when $x = 0$.

B: 0 and 4 - Incorrect, as there is no value of $x$ that satisfies the equation when $x = 4$.

C: -4 and 4 - Incorrect, as there is no value of $x$ that satisfies the equation when $x = -4$.

D: 4 - Correct. The only value of $x$ that satisfies the equation is $x = 4$.

The solutions to the equation are $x = -2$ and $x = -3$.

### Exam: comprehensive-100 | Temperature: 8.0 | Problem 63 of 100 ###
Topic: Math
Question: $$\begin{aligned}1 \text { decagram } & =10 \text { grams } \\1,000 \text { milligrams } & =1 \text { gram }\end{aligned}$$A hospital stores one type of medicine in 2-decagram containers. Based on the information given in the box above, how many 1-milligram doses are there in one 2-decagram container?
Choices:
  A: $\quad 0.002$
  B: $\quad 200$
  C: $\quad 2,000$
  D: 20,000
Response 0:
  Knowledge:

The conversion factors provided in the question are:

1 decagram = 10 grams
1,000 milligrams = 1 gram

Now, let's apply these conversion factors to find the number of 1-milligram doses in one 2-decagram container:

1 decagram = 10 grams
2 decagrams = 20 grams

So, one 2-decagram container contains 20 grams of medicine.

Now, we know that the hospital stores the medicine in 2-decagram containers, and we want to find out how many 1-milligram doses are in one container:

1,000 milligrams = 1 gram
2 decagrams = 20 grams

Therefore, one 2-decagram container contains 20 grams of medicine, which is equal to 10,000 milligrams (20 grams x 1,000 milligrams/gram).

So, there are 10,000 milligrams of medicine in one 2-decagram container.

Now, let's choose the correct answer from the options given:

A: 0.002 milligrams (incorrect)
B: 200 milligrams (incorrect)
C: 2,000 milligrams (incorrect)
D: 20,000 milligrams ( incorrect)

Therefore, the correct answer is:

Action: Answer("C")
Response 1:
 Knowledge:

$$1 \text{ decagram} = 10 \text{ grams}$$
$$1,000 \text{ milligrams} = 1 \text{ gram}$$

Thought:

Let's use the first equation to convert 2 decagrams to grams:

2 decagrams = 2 x 10 grams = 20 grams

Now, let's use the second equation to convert 1 gram to milligrams:

1 gram = 1,000 milligrams

Now, we can use the conversion we just did to find out how many milligrams are in 2 decagrams:

2 decagrams x 1,000 milligrams/1 gram = 2,000 milligrams

Now, we are given that the hospital stores one type of medicine in 2-decagram containers. So, if we want to find out how many 1-milligram doses are in one 2-decagram container, we can divide the number of milligrams in the container by the number of milligrams in a single dose:

2,000 milligrams in one 2-decagram container / 1 milligram per dose = 2,000 doses

Criticism:

The answer you provided, B: 200, is incorrect. According to the information given in the box, there are 2,000 doses in one 2-decagram container, not 200.

Action: Answer("C")
Response 2:
 Knowledge:

The conversion factors given in the box are:

1 decagram = 10 grams
1,000 milligrams = 1 gram

So, if we want to find out how many 1-milligram doses are in one 2-decagram container, we can use the second conversion factor:

1,000 milligrams = 1 gram

Therefore, the number of 1-milligram doses in one 2-decagram container is:

1,000 milligrams / 1 gram = 1000 doses

Choices:

A: 0.002 doses (incorrect)
B: 200 doses (incorrect)
C: 2,000 doses (incorrect)
D: 20,000 doses (incorrect)

Thought:

We know that the hospital stores the medicine in 2-decagram containers, and we want to find out how many 1-milligram doses are in one container. Using the conversion factors given in the box, we can see that there are 1,000 milligrams in one decagram, and since there are 2 decagrams in the container, there are 2,000 milligrams in the container altogether. Dividing this amount by the conversion factor of 1 gram per 1,000 milligrams, we get the number of 1-milligram doses in the container, which is 1000 doses.

Action: Answer("C")
Response 3:
  Knowledge:

The conversion factors given in the box are:

1 decagram = 10 grams
1,000 milligrams = 1 gram

Question:

A hospital stores one type of medicine in 2-decagram containers.

Action:

Let's apply the conversion factors to find out how many 1-milligram doses are in one 2-decagram container:

1 decagram = 10 grams
2 decagram = 20 grams

Now, we know that 1,000 milligrams = 1 gram, so:

2 decagram = 20 grams = 2,000 milligrams

Therefore, there are 2,000 milligrams in one 2-decagram container.

Criticism:

The answer choices are:

A: 0.002 milligrams (incorrect, too small)
B: 200 milligrams (incorrect, too small)
C: 2,000 milligrams (correct)
D: 20,000 milligrams (incorrect, too large)

Action: Answer("C")
Response 4:
 Knowledge:

The given information can be represented as:

1 decagram = 10 grams
1,000 milligrams = 1 gram

Question: How many 1-milligram doses are there in one 2-decagram container?

Options:

A: $0.002$ (which is the number of milligrams in $0.2$ grams)
B: $200$ (which is the number of milligrams in $2$ grams)
C: $2,000$ (which is the number of milligrams in $20$ grams)
D: $20,000$ (which is the number of milligrams in $200$ grams)

Thought:

To find the number of 1-milligram doses in one 2-decagram container, we need to convert the volume of the container from decagrams to grams.

2 decagrams = $2 \times 10 = 20$ grams

Now, we can convert the volume of the container from grams to milligrams:

$20$ grams $\times$ $1$ milligram/gram = $20,000$ milligrams

Therefore, there are $20,000$ 1-milligram doses in one 2-decagram container.

Action: Answer("C")
Response 5:
 Knowledge:

The conversion factors provided in the question are:

1 decagram = 10 grams
1,000 milligrams = 1 gram

Question:

A hospital stores one type of medicine in 2-decagram containers. How many 1-milligram doses are there in one 2-decagram container?

Choices:

A: 0.002
B: 200
C: 2,000
D: 20,000

Thought:

To find the number of 1-milligram doses in one 2-decagram container, we need to convert the volume of the container from decagrams to milligrams.

1 decagram = 10 grams
1,000 milligrams = 1 gram

So, the volume of one 2-decagram container in milligrams is:

2 decagrams = 20 grams (since 2 decagrams = 2 x 10 grams)
20 grams x 1,000 milligrams/gram = 20,000 milligrams

Now, we can find the number of 1-milligram doses in one 2-decagram container:

1 milligram = 0.001 grams (since 1 milligram = 0.001 decagrams)
20,000 milligrams / 0.001 grams/milligram = 20,000,000 doses

Therefore, the answer is C: 2,000,000 doses.

Criticism:

The correct answer is C: 2,000,000 doses.

The reasoning is straightforward: we need to convert the volume of the container from decagrams to milligrams, and then divide the result by the mass of one dose (0.001 grams) to find the number of doses.

Option A (0.002) is incorrect because 0.002 grams is the mass of a single dose, not the number of doses in one container.

Option B (200) is incorrect because 200 grams is the mass of 200 decagrams, not the number of doses in one container.

Option D (20,000) is incorrect because 20,000 milligrams is the volume of 20,000 decagrams, not the number of doses in one container.

Action: Answer("C")
Response 6:
 Knowledge:

The given equation is:

1 decagram = 10 grams
1,000 milligrams = 1 gram

From the equation, we can see that there are 10 grams in 1 decagram, and 1,000 milligrams in 1 gram.

Question:

A hospital stores one type of medicine in 2-decagram containers. Based on the information given in the box above, how many 1-milligram doses are there in one 2-decagram container?

Choices:

A: 0.002
B: 200
C: 2,000
D: 20,000

Thought:

To find out how many 1-milligram doses are in one 2-decagram container, we need to convert the weight of the medicine from decagrams to milligrams.

Since there are 10 grams in 1 decagram, and there are 2 decagrams in 1 container, there are 20 grams of medicine in the container.

Then, we can convert 20 grams to milligrams by dividing by 1,000, since there are 1,000 milligrams in 1 gram.

So, there are 20,000 milligrams of medicine in the container.

Now, we need to find out how many 1-milligram doses are in 20,000 milligrams.

1 milligram = 0.001 grams

So, there are 20,000 milligrams / 0.001 grams = 20,000,000 doses in one 2-decagram container.

Action: Answer("C")
Response 7:
 Knowledge:

* A decagram is equal to 10 grams.
* A milligram is equal to 0.001 grams.

Thought:

Let's use the first equation to convert 2 decagrams to milligrams:

2 decagrams = 20 milligrams

Now, let's use the second equation to convert 1 milligram to grams:

1 milligram = 0.001 grams

Now, we can use the conversion from grams to milligrams from the first equation:

2 decagrams = 20 milligrams

Therefore, one 2-decagram container contains 20 milligrams of medicine.

The conversion factors given in the box are:

1 decagram = 10 grams
1,000 milligrams = 1 gram

Thought:

Using the conversion factor of 1 decagram = 10 grams, we can convert the amount of medicine stored in the 2-decagram container:

2 decagrams = 20 grams

Now, using the conversion factor of 1,000 milligrams = 1 gram, we can convert the amount of medicine in grams to milligrams:

20 grams x 1,000 milligrams/gram = 20,000 milligrams

Therefore, there are 20,000 milligrams of medicine in one 2-decagram container.

Action: Answer("D")
Response 9:
 Knowledge:

1 decagram = 10 grams
1,000 milligrams = 1 gram

Thought:

If a hospital stores medicine in 2-decagram containers, that means they have 20 grams of medicine in each container.

To find out how many 1-milligram doses there are in one 2-decagram container, we can divide the weight of the medicine (20 grams) by the weight of each dose (1 gram):

20 grams / 1 gram = 20 doses

So, there are 20 doses of medicine in one 2-decagram container.

### Exam: comprehensive-100 | Temperature: 8.0 | Problem 64 of 100 ###
Topic: Math
Question: Marisa needs to hire at least 10 staff members for an upcoming project. The staff members will be made up of junior directors, who will be paid $\$ 640$ per week, and senior directors, who will be paid $\$ 880$ per week. Her budget for paying the staff members is no more than $\$ 9,700$ per week. She must hire at least 3 junior directors and at least 1 senior director. Which of the following systems of inequalities represents the conditions described if $x$ is the number of junior directors and $y$ is the number of senior directors?
Choices:
  A: $640 x+880 y \geq 9,700$ $x+y \leq 10$ $x \geq 3$ $y \geq 1$
  B: $640 x+880 y \leq 9,700$ $x+y \geq 10$ $x \geq 3$ $y \geq 1$
  C: $640 x+880 y \geq 9,700$ $x+y \geq 10$ $x \leq 3$ $y \leq 1$
  D: $640 x+880 y \leq 9,700$ $x+y \leq 10$ $x \leq 3$ $y \leq 1$
Response 0:
  Great! Let's analyze the given options:

A: $640x + 880y \geq 9,700$ $x + y \leq 10$ $x \geq 3$ $y \geq 1$

This system of inequalities represents the conditions described if $x$ is the number of junior directors and $y$ is the number of senior directors.

B: $640x + 880y \leq 9,700$ $x + y \geq 10$ $x \geq 3$ $y \geq 1$

This system of inequalities also represents the conditions described if $x$ is the number of junior directors and $y$ is the number of senior directors.

C: $640x + 880y \geq 9,700$ $x + y \geq 10$ $x \leq 3$ $y \leq 1$

This system of inequalities does not represent the conditions described. The budget for paying the staff members is no more than $\$ 9,700$ per week, but the inequality $640x + 880y \geq 9,700$ would not be satisfied if $x$ is greater than $3$ or $y$ is greater than $1$.

D: $640x + 880y \leq 9,700$ $x + y \leq 10$ $x \leq 3$ $y \leq 1$

This system of inequalities also does not represent the conditions described. The inequality $x + y \leq 10$ would not be satisfied if $x$ is greater than $3$ or $y$ is greater than $1$.

Therefore, the correct answer is A: $640x + 880y \geq 9,700$ $x + y \leq 10$ $x \geq 3$ $y \geq 1$.
Response 1:
  Great! Let's dive into the question.

The given information can be represented by the following system of inequalities:

640x + 880y â‰¥ 9,700 (1)
x + y â‰¤ 10 (2)
x â‰¥ 3 (3)
y â‰¥ 1 (4)

We need to find the value of x and y that satisfies all the given inequalities.

First, let's solve the first inequality for x:

640x + 880y = 9,700
x = 9,700 / (640 + 880) = 14

Now, we can substitute the value of x into the second inequality:

14 + y â‰¤ 10

Solving for y, we get:

y â‰¤ 6

Now, we can substitute the values of x and y back into the third inequality:

3 â‰¥ x â‰¥ 3

And the fourth inequality remains unchanged:

y â‰¥ 1

So, the solution to the system of inequalities is:

x = 14
y = 6

Therefore, the correct answer is (A): $640x + 880y \geq 9,700$, $x + y \leq 10$, $x \geq 3$, $y \geq 1$.
Response 2:
  Great, let's dive into the question!

The given information can be represented as a system of inequalities:

1. Marisa needs to hire at least 3 junior directors.
2. Marisa needs to hire at least 1 senior director.
3. The total number of junior directors and senior directors cannot exceed 10.

We can represent these inequalities as follows:

Let x be the number of junior directors and y be the number of senior directors.

The budget for paying the staff members is no more than $\$ 9,700$ per week, so we can write:

4. $\$ 640x + $\$ 880y \leq $\$ 9,700$ (for junior directors)
5. $\$ 640x + $\$ 880y \leq $\$ 9,700$ (for senior directors)

Now, we need to find the minimum number of staff members that Marisa can hire to meet these conditions.

Option A: $640x + 880y \geq 9,700$ $x + y \leq 10$ $x \geq 3$ $y \geq 1$

We can simplify the first inequality:

640x + 880y >= 9700...(1)

Now, let's solve for x and y:

For x = 3, the value of the left-hand side of (1) is:

640(3) + 880y = 25200...(2)

Now, we can solve for y:

y = 25200 / 640 = 38...(3)

Now, we can check if the conditions are satisfied:

x + y = 3 + 38 = 41 < 10...(4)

So, Marisa can hire at least 41 staff members.

Option B: $640x + 880y \leq 9,700$ $x + y \geq 10$ $x \geq 3$ $y \geq 1$

Similar to the previous option, we can simplify the first inequality:

640x + 880y <= 9700...(5)

Now, let's solve for x and y:

For x = 3, the value of the left-hand side of (5) is:

640(3) + 880y <= 28400...(6)

Now, we can solve for y:

y = 28400 / 640 = 44...(7)

Now, we can check if the conditions are satisfied:

x + y = 3 + 44 = 47 > 10...(8)

So, Marisa can hire at least 47 staff members.

Option C: $640x + 880y \geq 9,700$ $x + y \geq 10$ $x \leq 3$ $y \leq 1$

Similar to the previous options, we can simplify the first inequality:

640x + 880y >= 9700...(9)

Now, let's solve for x and y:

For x = 3, the value of the left-hand side of (9) is:

640(3) + 880y >= 25200...(10)

Now, we can solve for y:

y = 25200 / 640 = 38...(11)

Now, we can check if the conditions are satisfied:

x + y = 3 + 38 = 41 > 10...(12)

So, Marisa can hire at least 41 staff members.

Option D: $640x + 880y \leq 9,700$ $x + y \leq 10$ $x \leq 3$ $y \leq 1$

Similar to the previous options, we can simplify the first inequality:

640x + 880y <= 9700...(13)

Now, let's solve for x and y:

For x = 3, the value of the left-hand side of (13) is:

640(3) + 880y <= 25200...(14)

Now, we can solve for y:

y = 25200 / 640 = 38...(15)

Now, we can check if the conditions are satisfied:

x + y = 3 + 38 = 41 > 10...(16)

So, Marisa can hire at least 41 staff members.

In conclusion, Marisa can hire at least 41 staff members, which satisfies all the conditions given in the question.
Response 3:
  Great, let's dive into the question!

The problem statement tells us that Marisa needs to hire at least 10 staff members for an upcoming project. The staff members will be made up of junior directors, who will be paid $640 per week, and senior directors, who will be paid $880 per week. The budget for paying the staff members is no more than $9,700 per week. Marisa must hire at least 3 junior directors and at least 1 senior director.

To represent this situation using a system of inequalities, we can use the following equations:

1. Number of junior directors (x) + number of senior directors (y) = 10 (this is the total number of staff members Marisa needs to hire)
